document_title: Swim exercise in Caenorhabditis elegans extends neuromuscular and gut healthspan, enhances learning ability, and protects against neurodegeneration
summary_full: This study establishes a swim exercise regimen for the nematode Caenorhabditis elegans to investigate the systemic benefits of exercise on aging. The researchers found that multiple daily swim sessions in early adulthood are crucial for inducing long-lasting adaptations in various tissues, including body wall muscle, pharynx, intestine, and nervous system. The exercise regimen improved muscle gene expression, locomotion, mitochondrial morphology, and whole-animal mitochondrial respiration. It also extended pharyngeal and intestinal healthspans, enhanced learning ability, and protected against neurodegeneration in models of tauopathy, Alzheimer's disease, and Huntington's disease. Notably, these benefits persisted well into midlife, even after the exercise period ended. The study also demonstrated that exercise in postreproductive worms can improve locomotory vigor, suggesting exercise benefits are achievable at different life stages.
key_findings: A specific swim exercise regimen (3+3+2+2 sessions) in early adulthood C. elegans leads to molecular, morphological, and functional adaptations in body wall muscle.
Swim exercise improves whole-animal mitochondrial respiration and midlife survival.
Long-term swim exercise extends the healthspan of non-muscle tissues like the pharynx and intestine.
Exercised C. elegans show enhanced learning ability.
Swim exercise protects against neurodegeneration in C. elegans models of tauopathy, Alzheimer's disease, and Huntington's disease.
Exercise benefits are long-lasting, detectable well into midlife, suggesting early exercise can influence long-term health trajectories.
future_research_fields: Dissection of the molecular circuitry underlying system-wide exercise benefits.
Investigating transtissue signaling mechanisms initiated by exercise.
Exploring the role of early-life exercise in establishing long-term health.
Developing exercise protocols for older or compromised C. elegans strains.
Understanding how exercise impacts specific neuronal circuits and cognitive functions.

conclusions: Long-term swim exercise in early adult C. elegans induces robust, system-wide health benefits that extend neuromuscular, gut, and cognitive healthspan, and protect against neurodegeneration. These benefits are long-lasting, underscoring the potent impact of early exercise on aging trajectories and establishing C. elegans as a valuable model for dissecting the molecular mechanisms of exercise-dependent health.
impact_statement: This study demonstrates that exercise in a simple model organism can confer broad, long-lasting health benefits across multiple tissues, providing a foundation for understanding how exercise promotes healthy aging and protects against age-related diseases.
